channel.title: Command Help (Resolved, Thanks To Everyone!)

item.title: Command Help (Resolved, Thanks To Everyone!)
item.dc:creator: @nolan2131 nolan2131
item.description:
@nolan2131 wrote:

[quote=“Vain_, post:29, topic:533693”]i also messed up my code, by not including equals operators.

however, useful things to know for commands:

equalsIgnoreCase for all commands unless parameters are required. do not use equals, its stupid.

do not use unnecessary loops, and don’t execute the code inside the loops.

loop through actual players/data - not random numbers of iterations.

always check for space before adding items.
always check for items before deleting them.
always check for deleting the item before modifying data.
always check for data before adding items.

etc etc.[/quote]

Thanks man, I’ll keep all this in mind.

Read full topic

item.title: Command Help (Resolved, Thanks To Everyone!)
item.dc:creator: @Vain1 Vain_
item.description:
@Vain1 wrote:

i also messed up my code, by not including equals operators.

however, useful things to know for commands:

equalsIgnoreCase for all commands unless parameters are required. do not use equals, its stupid.

do not use unnecessary loops, and don’t execute the code inside the loops.

loop through actual players/data - not random numbers of iterations.

always check for space before adding items.
always check for items before deleting them.
always check for deleting the item before modifying data.
always check for data before adding items.

etc etc.

Read full topic

item.title: Command Help (Resolved, Thanks To Everyone!)
item.dc:creator: @nolan2131 nolan2131
item.description:
@nolan2131 wrote:

[quote=“Tutorial, post:26, topic:533693”][quote author=nolan2131 link=topic=652489.msg4372260#msg4372260 date=1381024751]

why not do ::getkillreward

and have it handled like:

public void killrewards(){ switch(c.KC){ case 100: c.getItems().addItem(0, 1); break; case 250: c.getItems().addItem(0, 1); break; default: c.sendMessage("You don't qualify for any rewards"); break; } }
Ignore conventions, and that’s just an idea…

I might give this a go

Okay, but what part are you stuck at? The code block that handles the command, or the entire system itself?

} if (playerCommand.startsWith("100kills")) { if (c.KC >= 100) { c.sendMessage("Congratulations on your 100th kill!"); c.getItems().addItem(1, 15050);

This is what I have going so far, tried multiple methods, but this current one gives the correct message, item, etc… Except that you can spawn the wings before 100kills
[/quote]

Your code would have to look like this:

if (command.equalsIgnoreCase("100kills")) {
if (c.killCount >= 100) {
c.sendMessage("Congratulations on your 100th kill!");
c.getItems().addItem(itemId, amount);
} else {
c.sendMessage("You need at least 100 kills to use this command!");
return;
}

As for the variable killCount, you will need to make sure the variable is being declared and initialized properly; for example, you need to make sure that you find the NPC death method and set the variable to increase (c.killCount++) every time an NPC is killed, so the variable is being stored. You need to also make sure you are saving the variable’s value to the player file so that it can be initialized back into the previous value as before once the server is restarted.

Edit: If you have done the following, I can only suggest you check the control flow of your if-statement, because if it isn’t being done properly it might not check for that variable’s value until AFTER the command has been executed, which sounds highly improbable due to the example you provided, but it is the only thing I can consider a possibility.[/quote]

Ok it’s finally working exactly how I imagined it, thank you Tutorial!

[quote=“Vain_, post:27, topic:533693”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=652489.msg4372254#msg4372254 date=1381023691]
why not do ::getkillreward

and have it handled like:

public void killrewards(){ switch(c.KC){ case 100: c.getItems().addItem(0, 1); break; case 250: c.getItems().addItem(0, 1); break; default: c.sendMessage("You don't qualify for any rewards"); break; } }
Ignore conventions, and that’s just an idea…
[/quote]because switch cases are taken literally and only checked if the object is equal to exactly that amount.

switch (number) { default: //default break; case 0: //"No kills."; break; case 100: //"100 kills"; break; this will only check if the player has exactly 0, or exactly 100. if neither return, it will fall directly to the default statement, which would be all kills, 1-99, or 101+ etc.

best option is just doing if blocks.

[code=Java]
//…
player.killcount += 1;

int qualifies = 0;

if (player.killcount > 0 && player.killcount < 100) {
    //not qualified
    qualifies = 0;
}
if (player.killcount > 100 && player.killcount < 200) {
    //qualified for 1st
    qualifies = 1;
    //addItem(id, amt);
}
if (player.killcount > 200 && player.killcount < 300) {
    //qualified for 2nd
    qualifies = 2;
    //addItem(id, amt);
}
if (player.killcount > 300 && player.killcount < 400) {
    //qualified for 3rd
    qualifies = 3;
    //addItem(id, amt);
}
if (player.killcount > 400 && player.killcount < 500) {
    //qualified for 4th
    qualifies = 4;
    //addItem(id, amt);
}
if (player.killcount > 500 && player.killcount < 600) {
    //qualified for 5th
    qualifies = 5;
    //addItem(id, amt);
}
if (player.killcount > 600 && player.killcount < 700) {
    //qualified for 6th
    qualifies = 6;
    //addItem(id, amt);
}
if (player.killcount > 700 && player.killcount < 800) {
    //qualified for 7th
    qualifies = 7;
    //addItem(id, amt);
}
if (player.killcount > 800 && player.killcount < 900) {
    //qualified for 8th
    qualifies = 8;
    //addItem(id, amt);
}
if (player.killcount > 900 && player.killcount < 1000) {
    //qualified for 9th
    qualifies = 9;
    //addItem(id, amt);
}
if (player.killcount > 1000 && player.killcount < 1100)
    //qualified for 10th
    qualifies = 10;
    //addItem(id, amt);
}

sendMessage("You currently have " + player.killcount + " kills, and qualify for a total of " +
        qualifies == 0 ? "no" : (qualifies == 10 ? "all" : qualifies) + " rewards.");
//...

[/code][/quote]

Yeah I had that issue with blocks when I added it, but I found the method I prefer most now thanks to Tutorial. Btw, you need to quit your job and break up with your girlfriend so you can play OldSchool more.

OT: Thanks again Tutorial, Sk8r, Null Amount, Docent, Vain_, Amirparvis, and Strucker (not really though). You all worked awesomely in trying to resolve this with me and I appreciate it!

Read full topic

item.description:

and have it handled like:

public void killrewards(){ switch(c.KC){ case 100: c.getItems().addItem(0, 1); break; case 250: c.getItems().addItem(0, 1); break; default: c.sendMessage("You don't qualify for any rewards"); break; } }
Ignore conventions, and that’s just an idea…[/quote]because switch cases are taken literally and only checked if the object is equal to exactly that amount.

switch (number) { default: //default break; case 0: //"No kills."; break; case 100: //"100 kills"; break; this will only check if the player has exactly 0, or exactly 100. if neither return, it will fall directly to the default statement, which would be all kills, 1-99, or 101+ etc.

best option is just doing if blocks.

    //...
    player.killcount += 1;

    int qualifies = 0;

    if (player.killcount > 0 && player.killcount < 100) {
        //not qualified
        qualifies = 0;
    }
    if (player.killcount > 100 && player.killcount < 200) {
        //qualified for 1st
        qualifies = 1;
        //addItem(id, amt);
    }
    if (player.killcount > 200 && player.killcount < 300) {
        //qualified for 2nd
        qualifies = 2;
        //addItem(id, amt);
    }
    if (player.killcount > 300 && player.killcount < 400) {
        //qualified for 3rd
        qualifies = 3;
        //addItem(id, amt);
    }
    if (player.killcount > 400 && player.killcount < 500) {
        //qualified for 4th
        qualifies = 4;
        //addItem(id, amt);
    }
    if (player.killcount > 500 && player.killcount < 600) {
        //qualified for 5th
        qualifies = 5;
        //addItem(id, amt);
    }
    if (player.killcount > 600 && player.killcount < 700) {
        //qualified for 6th
        qualifies = 6;
        //addItem(id, amt);
    }
    if (player.killcount > 700 && player.killcount < 800) {
        //qualified for 7th
        qualifies = 7;
        //addItem(id, amt);
    }
    if (player.killcount > 800 && player.killcount < 900) {
        //qualified for 8th
        qualifies = 8;
        //addItem(id, amt);
    }
    if (player.killcount > 900 && player.killcount < 1000) {
        //qualified for 9th
        qualifies = 9;
        //addItem(id, amt);
    }
    if (player.killcount > 1000 && player.killcount < 1100)
        //qualified for 10th
        qualifies = 10;
        //addItem(id, amt);
    }

    sendMessage("You currently have " + player.killcount + " kills, and qualify for a total of " +
            qualifies == 0 ? "no" : (qualifies == 10 ? "all" : qualifies) + " rewards.");
    //...

why not do ::getkillreward

and have it handled like:

[/quote]

Okay, but what part are you stuck at? The code block that handles the command, or the entire system itself?

} if (playerCommand.startsWith("100kills")) { if (c.KC >= 100) { c.sendMessage("Congratulations on your 100th kill!"); c.getItems().addItem(1, 15050);

This is what I have going so far, tried multiple methods, but this current one gives the correct message, item, etc… Except that you can spawn the wings before 100kills[/quote]

Your code would have to look like this:

if (command.equalsIgnoreCase("100kills")) {
if (c.killCount >= 100) {
c.sendMessage("Congratulations on your 100th kill!");

c.sendMessage("You need at least 100 kills to use this command!");

As for the variable killCount, you will need to make sure the variable is being declared and initialized properly; for example, you need to make sure that you find the NPC death method and set the variable to increase (c.killCount++) every time an NPC is killed, so the variable is being stored. You need to also make sure you are saving the variable’s value to the player file so that it can be initialized back into the previous value as before once the server is restarted.

Edit: If you have done the following, I can only suggest you check the control flow of your if-statement, because if it isn’t being done properly it might not check for that variable’s value until AFTER the command has been executed, which sounds highly improbable due to the example you provided, but it is the only thing I can consider a possibility.

item.title: Command Help (Resolved, Thanks To Everyone!)
item.dc:creator: @nolan2131 nolan2131
item.description:
@nolan2131 wrote:

Man, I’m just trying to make a code that gives someone the affiliated kill wings lol. Ex: Once someone gets 100 kills, they can type ::100kills and receive their 100 kill wings. The wings cant be lost on death, and they can use the command as much as they want.

ifcommandstartswith (“100kills”)
if (c.KC => 100)
additem (15051, 1)
sendmessag (“congratulations on your 100th kill.”)
else
You don’t have the required kills to spawn these wings.

That is the basic summary of what I’m going for.

Read full topic

			addItem(x, y);
		break;
		case 300:
			addItem(x2, y2);
		break;
		...

}[/code]

item.title: Command Help (Resolved, Thanks To Everyone!)
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“nolan2131, post:16, topic:533693”][quote author=Null Amount link=topic=652489.msg4372215#msg4372215 date=1381015131]
Let me rephrase, I think players are supposed to have the ability to claim it more than once if they want.
[/quote]

This, the item has no stats. I’m thinking of trying to implement it as to where you automatically get the item at your 250th kill, or make it obtainable from a shop and only be able to wear at 250 kills. Considering ideas at the moment. [/quote]
If the item has no stats, and you can get it as much as you like, why would you care to automatically give it to the player?
Just add it in the section that gives the player the +1 point for kills…
Only issue is it’d give it to you every kill after, unless you did if(c.KC == 250)…

item.title: Command Help (Resolved, Thanks To Everyone!)
item.dc:creator: @Null_Amount N_A
item.description:
@Null_Amount wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:11, topic:533693”]Why is everyone using startsWith?

if (playerCommand.equalsIgnoreCase("250kills")) { if (c.KC > 250){ c.sendMessage("Congratulations on your 250th kill!"); c.getItems().addItem(1, 15051); } }

I also suggest you adding a boolean to your playersave (or an int, so you can add more killstreaks later).

if (playerCommand.equalsIgnoreCase("250kills")) { if (c.KC > 250){ if(c.killrewardcount == 0){ c.sendMessage("Congratulations on your 250th kill!"); c.getItems().addItem(1, 15051); c.killrewardcount = 1; }else{ c.sendMessage("You have already claimed your reward for this streak!"); } }else{ c.sendMessage("You need "+ (250 - c.KC)+" kills to unlock this reward!"); } }[/quote]It’s not a kill streak reward, it’s just a reward that players can claim at 250 kill count if desired (I’m assuming based on op’s previous post)

Read full topic

item.title: Command Help (Resolved, Thanks To Everyone!)
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Why is everyone using startsWith?

if (playerCommand.equalsIgnoreCase("250kills")) { if (c.KC > 250){ c.sendMessage("Congratulations on your 250th kill!"); c.getItems().addItem(1, 15051); } }

I also suggest you adding a boolean to your playersave (or an int, so you can add more killstreaks later).

if (playerCommand.equalsIgnoreCase("250kills")) { if (c.KC > 250){ if(c.killrewardcount == 0){ c.sendMessage("Congratulations on your 250th kill!"); c.getItems().addItem(1, 15051); c.killrewardcount = 1; }else{ c.sendMessage("You have already claimed your reward for this streak!"); } }else{ c.sendMessage("You need "+ (250 - c.KC)+" kills to unlock this reward!"); } }

Read full topic

item.title: Command Help (Resolved, Thanks To Everyone!)
item.dc:creator: @amirparvis amirparvis
item.description:
@amirparvis wrote:

Try this

if (playerCommand.startsWith(“250kills”)) {
if (c.KC >= 250)
c.sendMessage(“Congratulations on your 250th kill!”);
c.getItems().addItem(15051, 1);

                    }

That should work better

item.title: Command Help (Resolved, Thanks To Everyone!)
item.dc:creator: @nolan2131 nolan2131
item.description:
@nolan2131 wrote:

[quote=“chazion, post:1, topic:533696”][code=java]
//just the idea

if(cmd.equals(“250”)) {
//check whether or not they have the killcount requrement met or exceeded
//sendmessage youve reiceved the 250 kill count reward
//give the reward
///MAKE SURE YOU RESET THE KILL COUNT killcount = 0;
}

[/code][/quote]
It’s not a killstreak, I don’t want it to reset the killcount.

[quote=“Null Amount, post:4, topic:533693”][quote author=nolan2131 link=topic=652489.msg4372042#msg4372042 date=1380947050]
Thanks for the advice, I’ve implemented it to my current version. For some reason it gives me a full inventory of toolkits now, with no message. Lol Wut?
[/quote]I believe the parameters for the addItem method is itemId, amount, not amount, itemId. You should also rename your variables so it follows naming conventions (camelCase).[/quote][quote=“Docent, post:8, topic:533693”]I know why it gives you a full inv of toolkits…

replace [code=java]if (playerCommand.startsWith(“250kills”)) {
if (c.KC > 250)
c.sendMessage(“Congratulations on your 250th kill!”);
c.getItems().addItem(1, 15051);

                    }[/code]

with [code=java]if (playerCommand.startsWith(“250kills”)) {
if (c.KC > 250)
c.sendMessage(“Congratulations on your 250th kill!”);
c.getItems().addItem(15051, 1);

                    }[/code][/quote]

I’m going to go ahead and sell my computer and give up on life. Lol, thanks for pointing this out.

Read full topic
